course.subject: MATH
course.name: Advanced Numerical Methods I
course.description: Numerical solution of differential equations, finite difference method, finite element methods, spectral methods and boundary integral methods.  Basic theory of convergence, stability and error estimates.

reviews.author: yabayaba123
reviews.title: Okay but not that appropriate for engineering students
reviews.comment_content:
The material is not that easy to read, for an engineering student. There are several applications that are very theoretical and I would say not very appropriate for my purpose. However, I do think that for someone from a math background, it is okay and is very detailed.

I think the course covered the main differential equations. I just think that there should be more lessons on how to apply it well, especially in certain kinds of engineering equations and scenarios.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is good in teaching and is very enthusiastic. What I like about him is he seems to be really enjoying what he teaches. He shows up on time in class and is always available for consultation. He explains concepts well but for very complex ones, he has a hard time explaining it to students from non-math backgrounds.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is okay and quite lenient, but still is fair. For instance, a well-done homework normally receives around 9/10 or 10/10. The grading also takes too long, probably at the end of the term. So you don't have a good gauge on how your grades are.
reviews.comment_workload: For me, I think there are too many homework, considering this is a PG course. Although I have expected it based on stories by other students. There are many homework that are given weekly or every other week. Each homework typically has 3-4 questions, but they have sub-questions, which make them longer. There is also a final project wherein you have to choose any differential equation from your field and present your numerical assessment about it. It's quite flexible, which is pretty nice.

reviews.author: Aaron W
reviews.comment_content:
The course covers different numerical methods applied to PDEs. There were 6 parts to the course:
1. Finite difference method
2. Stability and Truncation error analysis
3. Variational principle and finite element method
4. Convergence analysis and error estimates
5. Spectral method
6. Finite Volume Method
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Wang was quite a good teacher and was able to explain the concepts quite clearly. The lecture notes are a bit messy and hard to understand by themselves, so I recommend going to class (or watching the lecture videos).
reviews.comment_grading:
4 Homeworks (40%)
Take home final project (60%)

Me:
Homeworks: 95.8/100
Final Project: 100/100
Overall: 98.3/100
Grade: A

Very easy to get a good grade, but to get an A+ you have to be careful (I only made 2 minor mistakes in the homeworks)
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload of the course is very light. (although we only had 4 homeworks instead of the planned 8-10 for some reason). The homeworks are just applying proofs/concepts we learned in the lecture to other problems.

We had two weeks to do the take-home project, which was also similar to the HWs but required us to do some simulation (using MATLAB or another programming language). There were only 3 problems so it only took a day or two to do.

reviews.author: YS
reviews.comment_content: Not going to repeat what the previous review mentioned. He decomposed the content of "Numerical Solution of Partial Differential Equations: An Introduction" by K. W. Morton (up to Ch. 7?) into several parts. He also added the relaxation methods (originally from 5312?)
reviews.comment_teaching: Better attend his lectures because he would add (e.g. more examples or more detailed steps) on the lecture notes during the lessons. The textbook would be a good supplement to the lecture notes in case you want some more examples. However it is painful if you only read the textbook, and you may miss something else he taught.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments 40%
Final project 60%

Xiaoping do us good grading the project. I thought I didn't explain the idea in one part clear enough but he still gave me full mark.

Edit: but it turns out, as Aaron mentioned, that the A/A+ cutoff is very strict, so...
reviews.comment_workload:
Has coding for both assignments and finals but the codes can be pretty easily googled. Any language would be good but Xiaoping prefers Matlab(/Octave).

Other than that the written portion of the project is quite challenging because it takes time to think about what the questions want to know.

reviews.author: 落叶飘满天空
reviews.title: 小平是个好老师
reviews.comment_content:
和官网介绍差不多（这是抄的2019-20 Fall的，不过跟18-19 Fall差不多）

Course Description: After providing some related background on elliptic PDEs and numerical methods, the course will cover:
Finite difference method
Stability and Truncation error analysis
Variational principle and finite element method
Convergence analysis and error estimates
Spectral method
Boundary element method
Finite Volume Method
Numerical solution of some nonlinear elliptic PDEs
reviews.comment_teaching:
王老师英语不错，讲得到位，唯一的缺点可能是声音不大，不过我都坐第一或者第二排所以问题不大。

这堂课推导步骤（抄笔记）很重要，所以坐前排是明智的。
reviews.comment_grading:
感觉还行，拿A-主要是因为自己平时作业没有好好写。
HW 1:8/10
HW 2: 10/10
HW 3: 7/10
Project 1: 15/20
Final Project: 未知
reviews.comment_workload:
workload算是比较轻的。说是有8-10个homework但到最后也只有3个homework 1个project
HW1: 一道题
HW2: 一道题
HW3: 两道题
Project 1: 用explicit和implicit scheme 去解heat equation验证稳定性，同时也要写代码。


Final Project：三道大题。给了很长时间= =花了几天做了两道以后找同学讨论，发现全是textbook课后习题，以及网上居然都有答案。（答案比较简略，还是得看懂了自己写步骤）也有代码部分。

reviews.author: elioe
reviews.comment_content: content as described on the website. Well structured, the book my Morton (Numerical Solution of PDE) is really helpful.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is really good, great english. I can't complain.
reviews.comment_grading: I have to write this feedback to see more than only one review for every class. I have not been graded for this class yet.
reviews.comment_workload: A few assignment and programming projects with matlab are due during the semester. The homeworks were quite difficult for me but the above mentioned book is really helpful. Being familiar with Matlab helps a lot.
